title: Trump Says He Discussed Possible Defense Treaty With Israel
text:
President Trump said he discussed a possible “mutual defense treaty” between the U.S. and Israel in a call with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, signaling support for the country’s embattled leader days before a tough re-election vote.

Mr. Trump tweeted Saturday that the leaders spoke about the possibility of a treaty that would “further anchor the tremendous alliance between our two countries,” adding that they hoped to continue talks after Tuesday’s election.

“I look forward to continuing those discussions after the Israeli Elections when we meet at the United Nations later this month!” Mr. Trump said.

Mr. Netanyahu thanked Mr. Trump for his announcement on Twitter and said he looked forward to meeting him at the United Nations General Assembly.

“The Jewish State has never had a greater friend in the White House,” Mr. Netanyahu said.

The White House didn’t immediately provide additional comment.

Mr. Netanyahu is locked in a close election contest with his main rival, former Gen. Benny Gantz, with final polls ahead of the vote suggesting that neither has a clear path to forming a government.

The government-formation process will take several weeks, possibly running up against the U.N. meeting. If it is clear Mr. Netanyahu is no longer the prime minister, he is unlikely to go.

Negotiations on a mutual defense pact could take months. Such a pact would obligate both sides to come to each other’s defense in the event of military conflict, and would go beyond the significant intelligence sharing already under way, though the sides would have to work out the details.

Mr. Gantz, head of the centrist Blue and White party, came out against the possible defense pact earlier this month. Mr. Gantz and many other members of Israel’s security establishment believe a defense pact could limit the Israeli military’s freedom of action by forcing closer military cooperation between the allies.

“This is not what we want,” Mr. Gantz said. “We haven’t asked anyone to be killed for our sakes, we haven’t asked anyone to fight for us, and we haven’t asked anyone for the right to defend the state of Israel.”

The U.S. has several mutual collective defense arrangements, the most prominent of which is the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Under NATO’s common defense provision, known as article 5, if any of NATO’s 29 countries is attacked, all NATO countries are considered to be under attack as well and obligated to join in defending the target. The alliance was designed as a defense treaty to deter aggression from what was the Soviet Union.

Mr. Netanyahu has been campaigning on the strength of his relationship with President Trump and other world leaders and has been looking to Mr. Trump to show his support before the vote.

Ahead of Israel’s April elections—which Mr. Netanyahu won but then failed to cobble together a coalition—Mr. Trump recognized Israel’s sovereignty over the Golan Heights and hosted Mr. Netanyahu for a visit in the White House.

Since Mr. Trump has been president, he has recognized Jerusalem as Israel’s capital and taken Mr. Netanyahu’s advice to pull out of the 2015 Iranian nuclear deal.

Recently, Mr. Netanyahu and other Israeli officials have been urging Mr. Trump not to hold discussions with Iran President Hassan Rouhani, arguing that Washington should continue to increase economic pressure on Tehran.

Israel has been carrying out airstrikes in Syria, Iraq and Lebanon aimed at combating Iran’s ability to move weapons it could use to strike Israel and to prevent Iran from entrenching itself close to Israel’s borders. It has stepped up the campaign in recent weeks, which officials said was tied to Hezbollah’s acceleration of efforts in Lebanon to build precision guided missiles.
